questions.question: What characteristic defined the Zeroth Generation of computers (1642-1945)?

options.text: They were mechanical systems without electronic components.
They utilized vacuum tubes for processing.
They were based on transistor technology.
They introduced the first Integrated Circuits.

questions.explanation: According to the historical overview, the Zeroth Generation (1642-1945) consisted of mechanical devices. Vacuum tubes appeared in the First Generation.

questions.question: Which technology was the primary component of First Generation computers (1945-1955)?

options.text: Transistors
Vacuum tubes
Integrated Circuits
Microprocessors

questions.explanation: The First Generation of computers (1945-1955) utilized vacuum tubes. The Cathode Ray Tube (CRT) was also mainly employed during this era.

questions.question: What major advancement marked the Second Generation of computers (1955-1965)?

options.text: The invention of the mechanical analytical engine.
The introduction of Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI).
The replacement of vacuum tubes with transistors.
The development of graphical user interfaces (GUIs).

questions.explanation: The Second Generation saw the replacement of vacuum tubes with transistors, making computers smaller, faster, and more reliable.

questions.question: Which technology was introduced during the Third Generation (1965-1980)?

options.text: Artificial Intelligence neural networks.
Vacuum tubes.
Personal Computers (PCs).
Integrated Circuits (ICs).

questions.explanation: The Third Generation introduced Integrated Circuits (ICs), replacing transistors 68]. This era also saw the rise of minicomputers.

questions.question: What key technological development characterizes the Fourth Generation of computers (1980-present)?

options.text: The use of punch cards for input.
The advent of microprocessors and VLSI.
The creation of the first mechanical calculator.
The exclusive use of assembly language.

questions.explanation: The Fourth Generation is characterized by Personal Computers and VLSI (Very Large Scale Integration), seeing the advent of microprocessors that integrate thousands of ICs on a single chip.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the Arithmetic & Logic Unit (ALU)?

options.text: It manages the transfer of data between the HDD and RAM.
It stores the operating system permanently.
It performs arithmetic (+, -) and logic (AND, OR) operations.
It acts as the physical interface for I/O devices.

questions.explanation: The ALU allows required arithmetic operations (like addition and subtraction) or logic operations (like AND, OR) to be carried out while a program is being run.

questions.question: How is computer memory structured fundamentally?

options.text: It is a combination of memory cells, where each cell length is 8 bits.
It is a continuous wave of analog signals.
It is composed of decimal storage units called 'decits'.
It consists solely of mechanical switches.

questions.explanation: Memory is a combination of memory cells. Each cell length is 8 bits. Every data stored in computer memory follows bit data such as 0's and 1's.

questions.question: What are the two main categories of computer memory?

options.text: Volatile and Non-volatile Memory.
HDD and SSD Storage.
Digital and Analog Memory.
Primary (Internal) and Secondary (External) Memory.

questions.explanation: Computer memory is divided into Primary Memory (Internal) and Secondary Memory (External).

questions.question: Which of the following contains only examples of Primary Memory?

options.text: HDD, SSD, and Flash Drive.
RAM, ROM, and Hybrid (EEPROM).
Compact Disk, Floppy Disk, and Magnetic Tape.
Monitor, Keyboard, and Mouse.

questions.explanation: Primary memory includes RAM (SRAM, DRAM), ROM (PROM, EPROM), and Hybrid types like EEPROM and NVRAM.

questions.question: What is the key difference between Internal (Primary) and External (Secondary) memory regarding accessibility?

options.text: External memory is faster than Internal memory.
Internal memory is accessible via I/O modules, while External is direct.
Internal memory is directly accessible by the processor, while External is accessible via I/O modules.
External memory stores data temporarily, while Internal stores it permanently.

questions.explanation: Internal Memory (Primary) is directly accessible by the processor. External Memory (Secondary) is accessible by the processor via I/O Modules.

questions.question: What is the function of a CPU Register?

options.text: A small storage location within a CPU to hold data or addresses temporarily.
A large storage area for archiving old files.
A device used to input human-readable data.
A permanent storage for the operating system kernel.

questions.explanation: A register is a small permanent storage location within a CPU used to hold data, information, and addresses temporarily. The data is not stored permanently.

questions.question: Which statement accurately describes Cache Memory?

options.text: It is the slowest form of memory in the hierarchy.
It is located in the secondary storage devices.
It stores data permanently even when the computer is off.
It resides between the CPU and main memory to store frequently used data.

questions.explanation: Cache memory is one of the fastest memories. It resides between the CPU and main memory and stores all frequently used data to help the CPU access data quicker.

questions.question: What is the definition of Main Memory?

options.text: An external storage area used for backup tapes.
An internal storage area availed to store data and programs either permanently or temporarily.
A specialized unit strictly for arithmetic calculations.
A graphical interface for user interaction.

questions.explanation: Main memory is defined as an internal storage area in a computer which is availed to store data and programs either permanently or temporarily.

questions.question: How is 'Computer Architecture' defined?

options.text: The process of manufacturing silicon chips.
The design of graphical icons for operating systems.
A specification detailing how software and hardware standards interact to form a computer system.
The physical arrangement of cables within a server room.

questions.explanation: Computer architecture is a specification detailing how a set of software and hardware technology standards interact to form a computer system or platform. It acts as an interface between hardware and software.

questions.question: What is a core feature of the Von Neumann Architecture?

options.text: It requires data to be fed manually while running.
It holds both programs and data in the same memory.
It prevents the CPU from accessing memory directly.
It was designed specifically for parallel processing without a CPU.

questions.explanation: Developed in 1945, the Von Neumann Architecture concept allows the computer memory to hold programs as well as data. It also enables the CPU to access memory directly.

questions.question: Which of the following lists correctly identifies components of the Von Neumann Model?

options.text: MAR, MDR, PC, CIR, ALU, and Control Unit.
Keyboard, Mouse, Monitor, and Printer.
HDD, SSD, Flash Drive, and Cloud Storage.
Windows, Linux, MacOS, and Android.

questions.explanation: The Von Neumann Architecture Model includes specific components such as the Memory Address Register (MAR), Memory Data Register (MDR), Program Counter (PC), Current Instruction Register (CIR), ALU, and Control Unit.

questions.question: Which of these are examples of specific Computer Architectures mentioned in the course?

options.text: TCP/IP, HTTP, and FTP.
Photoshop, Excel, and Word.
CRT, LCD, and LED.
x86, SPARC, and PowerPC.

questions.explanation: The course lists specific examples of computer architectures including the x86 (Intel and AMD), the SPARC (Sun Microsystems), and the PowerPC (Apple, IBM, Motorola).

questions.question: What does the x86 architecture specification define?

options.text: How the monitor displays colors.
How the power supply regulates voltage.
How a processor handles and executes instructions passed from the OS.
How the keyboard maps keys to characters.

questions.explanation: x86 architecture defines how a processor handles and executes different instructions passed from the operating system (OS) and software program.

questions.question: Into which categories can I/O (External) devices be categorized?

options.text: Processing, Storage, and Retrieval.
Human readable, Machine readable, and Communications.
Primary, Secondary, and Tertiary.
Internal, External, and Hybrid.

questions.explanation: External devices are categorized into Human readable (e.g., Printers), Machine readable (e.g., Sensors), and Communications (e.g., Modems).
